Query the GitHub API

Source: R/gh.R
gh.Rd

This is an extremely minimal client. You need to know the API to be able to use this client. All this function does is:

  • Try to substitute each listed parameter into endpoint, using the {parameter} notation.

  • If a GET request (the default), then add all other listed parameters as query parameters.

  • If not a GET request, then send the other parameters in the request body, as JSON.

  • Convert the response to an R list using jsonlite::fromJSON().

Usage

gh(
  endpoint,
  ...,
  per_page = NULL,
  .per_page = NULL,
  .token = NULL,
  .destfile = NULL,
  .overwrite = FALSE,
  .api_url = NULL,
  .method = "GET",
  .limit = NULL,
  .accept = "application/vnd.github.v3+json",
  .send_headers = NULL,
  .progress = TRUE,
  .params = list(),
  .max_wait = 600,
  .max_rate = NULL
)

Arguments

endpoint

GitHub API endpoint. Must be one of the following forms:

  • METHOD path, e.g. GET /rate_limit,

  • path, e.g. /rate_limit,

  • METHOD url, e.g. GET https://api.github.com/rate_limit,

  • url, e.g. https://api.github.com/rate_limit.

If the method is not supplied, will use .method, which defaults to "GET".

...

Name-value pairs giving API parameters. Will be matched into endpoint placeholders, sent as query parameters in GET requests, and as a JSON body of POST requests. If there is only one unnamed parameter, and it is a raw vector, then it will not be JSON encoded, but sent as raw data, as is. This can be used for example to add assets to releases. Named NULL values are silently dropped. For GET requests, named NA values trigger an error. For other methods, named NA values are included in the body of the request, as JSON null.

per_page, .per_page

Number of items to return per page. If omitted, will be substituted by max(.limit, 100) if .limit is set, otherwise determined by the API (never greater than 100).

.token

Authentication token. Defaults to gh_token().

.destfile

Path to write response to disk. If NULL (default), response will be processed and returned as an object. If path is given, response will be written to disk in the form sent. gh writes the response to a temporary file, and renames that file to .destfile after the request was successful. The name of the temporary file is created by adding a -<random>.gh-tmp suffix to it, where <random> is an ASCII string with random characters. gh removes the temporary file on error.

.overwrite

If .destfile is provided, whether to overwrite an existing file. Defaults to FALSE. If an error happens the original file is kept.

.api_url

Github API url (default: https://api.github.com). Used if endpoint just contains a path. Defaults to GITHUB_API_URL environment variable if set.

.method

HTTP method to use if not explicitly supplied in the endpoint.

.limit

Number of records to return. This can be used instead of manual pagination. By default it is NULL, which means that the defaults of the GitHub API are used. You can set it to a number to request more (or less) records, and also to Inf to request all records. Note, that if you request many records, then multiple GitHub API calls are used to get them, and this can take a potentially long time.

.accept

The value of the Accept HTTP header. Defaults to "application/vnd.github.v3+json" . If Accept is given in .send_headers, then that will be used. This parameter can be used to provide a custom media type, in order to access a preview feature of the API.

.send_headers

Named character vector of header field values (except Authorization, which is handled via .token). This can be used to override or augment the default User-Agent header: "https://github.com/r-lib/gh".

.progress

Whether to show a progress indicator for calls that need more than one HTTP request.

.params

Additional list of parameters to append to .... It is easier to use this than ... if you have your parameters in a list already.

.max_wait

Maximum number of seconds to wait if rate limited. Defaults to 10 minutes.

.max_rate

Maximum request rate in requests per second. Set this to automatically throttle requests.

Value

Answer from the API as a gh_response object, which is also a list. Failed requests will generate an R error. Requests that generate a raw response will return a raw vector.

See also

gh_gql() if you want to use the GitHub GraphQL API, gh_whoami() for details on GitHub API token management.

Examples

## Repositories of a user, these are equivalent
gh("/users/hadley/repos", .limit = 2)

#>     "body": "Currently dplyr warns users who accidentally use `=` instead of `==`. \nHowever, this does not occur if a logical is passed as the named variable.\n\n## Demonstration\n\n\n\n\n\n``` r\nlibrary(dplyr)\n\nmtcars$big_cyl <- mtcars$cyl > 4\n# Mistaking = for == silently fails, returning the whole dataset\nfilter(mtcars, big_cyl = TRUE) |>\n  nrow()\n#> [1] 32\n```\nCorrectly using `==` for comparison\n```r\n# Correctly using ==.\nfilter(mtcars, big_cyl == TRUE) |>\n  nrow()\n#> [1] 21\n```\n\nI think while doing `x == TRUE` is bad practice, this is bound to trip up some users and an error should be thrown.\n\n## Additional context\n\nExample of the error working correctly:\n``` r\n# version 1.1.4\ndplyr::filter(mtcars, cyl = \"4\")\n#> Error in `dplyr::filter()`:\n#> ! We detected a named input.\n#> ℹ This usually means that you've used `=` instead of `==`.\n#> ℹ Did you mean `cyl == \"4\"`?\n```\n\nInterestingly if the TRUE is in a vector the error *is* thrown.\n\n``` r\ndplyr::filter(mtcars, big_cyl = c(TRUE))\n#> Error in `dplyr::filter()`:\n#> ! We detected a named input.\n#> ℹ This usually means that you've used `=` instead of `==`.\n#> ℹ Did you mean `big_cyl == c(TRUE)`?\n```\n\n",

This is what the [`{dplyover}`](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover) package allows with its [`across2()` and `across2x()` functions](https://timteafan.github.io/dplyover/reference/across2.html):\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# remotes::install_github(\"TimTeaFan/dplyover\")\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(dplyover)\r\n\r\niris %>% \r\n  group_by(Species) %>%\r\n  summarise(across2x(starts_with(\"Sepal\"), starts_with(\"Petal\"), cor))\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 5\r\n#>   Species   Sepal.Length_Petal.L…¹ Sepal.Length_Petal.W…² Sepal.Width_Petal.Le…³\r\n#>   <fct>                      <dbl>                  <dbl>                  <dbl>\r\n#> 1 setosa                     0.267                  0.278                  0.178\r\n#> 2 versicol…                  0.754                  0.546                  0.561\r\n#> 3 virginica                  0.864                  0.281                  0.401\r\n#> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​Sepal.Length_Petal.Length, ²​Sepal.Length_Petal.Width,\r\n#> #   ³​Sepal.Width_Petal.Length\r\n#> # ℹ 1 more variable: Sepal.Width_Petal.Width <dbl>\r\n\r\ncor(iris[1:50,]$Sepal.Length, iris[1:50,]$Petal.Length)\r\n#> [1] 0.2671758\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-07-17 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n\r\nThe creation of the `{dplyover}` began with this [issue](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4834), which –at that time– recommended putting these features in an adjacent package. \r\n\r\n`{dplyover}` has really saved me and my colleagues a huge amount of time. However, it is not on CRAN, some bugs [[1](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/21), [2](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/23)] have been found, enhancement in the `{dplyr}` package are [not currently supported](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/1), and the last commit is 3 years old.\r\n\r\nDo you think these really useful functions could be included in the `{dplyr}` package? #>     "body": "## Problem\r\n\r\nThanks @AMDraghici for your suggestions!\r\n\r\nFor example, in `bind_rows`, if the first input is a `data.table`, the output table can have corrupt indexing due to how the underlying `dplyr_reconstruct` function deals with the attributes of the two inputs\r\n\r\n## Reprex\r\n\r\nThe example below shows that the index attribute can be incorrect for the output. \r\n\r\n```r\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(5, 2:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"c\") # Create a data.table\r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil. This is necessary for the subset error below to happen in data.table. But it is not necessary to re-produce the corrupted index. \r\n> a[cola == 4] # Give data.table a secondary index (\"cola\" column) by auto-indexing\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$index # The secondary index is set correctly\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, colb = 2, colc=3, cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::bind_rows(list(a,b))\r\n> \r\n> combined # combined is a data.table, with 5 rows\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     5 0.5535855 0.6024416      c\r\n2:     2 0.3407051 0.9291365      c\r\n3:     3 0.5007208 0.6823528      c\r\n4:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n5:    -1 2.0000000 3.0000000      d\r\n> \r\n> attributes(combined)$index # Wrong! length of secondary index is only 4\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 4 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold # Wrong! The last row of combined should be returned\r\n> combined\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola       colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>      <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     1 0.83105427 0.4214379      c\r\n2:     2 0.05702599 0.1354883      c\r\n3:     3 0.63866251 0.1644736      c\r\n4:     4 0.21441544 0.2198251      c\r\n5:    -1 2.00000000 3.0000000      d\r\n```\r\n## Cause\r\n\r\nIn the `bind_rows` function, `dplyr_reconstruct` is used to set attributes for the output dataframe. \r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/R/bind-rows.R#L79\r\n\r\n```r\r\nout <- dplyr_reconstruct(out, first)\r\n```\r\nLooking at the `dplyr_reconstruct` function, it is essentially giving all attributes other than `names` and `row.names` in `template_` to `data`.\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/src/reconstruct.cpp#L36 \r\n\r\nIn the case above, all attributes of `first` (which has four rows), including index are given to `out`, which has five rows. This causes the problem. \r\n\r\n## Impact\r\n\r\nBecause the `data.table` produced by `bind_rows` has corrupted secondary index, the filter functionality of `data.table` is skipping some rows when filtering by the index column. \r\nAlso, I found that this problem is not limited to `bind_rows`. Other `dplyr` functions that calls `dplyr_reconstruct` can result in data.tables with corrupted secondary index. For example, the `full_join` function can also produce unexpected results due to corrupted secondary index.  \r\n\r\n```\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(1:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil\r\n> a[cola == 3]\r\n       cola         colb         colc      cold\r\n   <int>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     3 0.9968646 0.8137836      d\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, cole = \"e\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::full_join(a, b, by = \"cola\")\r\n> \r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 5 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold,cole\r\n```",

#>     "body": "See https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7044\r\n\r\nIn particular, note that `arrange(df, x)` will sort `x` using the C locale if it is a character vector. But `arrange(df, -desc(x))` (i.e. invert the `desc()` call, giving you the original order in theory) will sort `x` using the user's locale.\r\n\r\nNormally a call like `desc(x)` is recognized and we don't even actually call `desc()` under the hood, we translate it to a `\"desc\"` value for the `directions` argument of `vec_order_radix()`, but in this case the `-` interferes and we actually evaluate the call.\r\n\r\nThat ends up calling `desc()` which does `-xtfrm(x)`, and `xtfrm()` ends up using `base::order(x)`, utilizing the user's locale.\r\n\r\nI don't think we should remove usage of `xtfrm()` in `desc()`, since that is a generic that people have probably written S3 methods for, but maybe we can have special behavior for unclassed character vectors where it utilized `vec_rank()` instead (which uses the C locale)? It would not be a perfect fix, but it may be good enough.",

#>     "body": "Should we guarantee that the functions used in a rowwise `mutate()` or `summarize()` or `reframe()` always see length-one input? This is currently the case for everything but empty input, which creates a corner case to be worked around in user code. The example below shows `mutate()`, but the behavior is very similar for `summarize()` and `reframe()`\r\n\r\n``` r\r\noptions(conflicts.policy = list(warn = FALSE))\r\n\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1L) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1:3) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> [1] 2\r\n#> [1] 3\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n#> 2     2          2\r\n#> 3     3          3\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\n# Should this print `NA_integer_` ?\r\ntibble(a = integer()) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> integer(0)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#> # ℹ 2 variables: a <int>, print(a) <int>\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-06-12 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>",

#>     "body": "Hi @hadley and @DavisVaughan,\r\n\r\nThis merge request aims to align the mutate functionality with that of transmute. Presently, the documentation states that the equivalent of transmute is mutate(.keep=\"none\"). However, it's important to note that this function retains the column order, unlike transmute.\r\n\r\nAfter reviewing the bug reported here: https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6861, I concur that there should be a fifth variant of keep, named \"transmute.\"\r\n\r\nThis proposal should also be implemented in the following tidyverse libraries:\r\n- [ ] [dtplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dtplyr)  \r\n- [ ] [dbplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr):  https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr/pull/1508\r\n\r\nAnd in the following third party libraries:\r\n- [ ] [duckplyr](https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr): https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr/pull/176\r\n- [ ] [arrow](https://github.com/apache/arrow/r)\r\n- [ ] [tidypolars](https://github.com/etiennebacher/tidypolars)\r\n\r\nThis change opens the possibility of un-superseded transmute. For example, you could implement that when a user calls transmute, it internally executes mutate(.keep=\"transmute\"). This would greatly benefit veteran users who have extensively used transmute in their projects. Additionally, it improves code readability, as a simple transmute call is clearer than mutate(.keep=\"transmute\").\r\n\r\nBelow I leave an example comparing transmute with mutate(.keep = \"transmute\")\r\n\r\n```\r\nexample <- tibble(\r\n  group = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\"),\r\n  old = c(1, 2, 3, 4)\r\n)\r\n\r\n# transmute --------------------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% transmute(\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") --------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% mutate(\r\n  .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + transmute ---------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  transmute(\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") ---------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\", by = ...) ----------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>%  \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    .by = \"group\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n  )\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nRegards,\r\n\r\n",

#>     "body": "This would be useful in packages to avoid cran warnings as `pick()` is the new preferred way.\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\noptions(lifecycle_verbosity = \"error\")\r\nmtcars <- utils::head(mtcars, n = 6)\r\n# distinct -----------\r\n# renaming generally makes a lot of sense, as distinct is like `transmute(...)` + `distinct()`\r\n# consider this in EDA\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = vs)\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\n# as it is equivalent to: (to avoid cran warnings)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = .data$vs)\r\n# Before dplyr 1.1, `across()` was recommended, which works, but .fns = NULL is soft-deprecated.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# The alternative when you may not know variable names in a package\r\n# with `pick()` should therefore work too, but errors.\r\n# I think it should work\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `distinct()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n# Similarly:\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n\r\n# I would expect distinct() and transmute()  + distinct() to be same as above (and it is!) ---\r\n# transmute() is still very useful as it is mutate + select in a single call)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = .data$vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n# I think this should be allowed.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#> Error in `transmute()`:\r\n#> ℹ In argument: `pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nNow comes `arrange()`...\r\n\r\n## arrange() \r\n\r\nWhile I believe `distinct()` should accept renaming under any circonstances, I believe that accepting renaming in `arrange()` is inconsistent, as `arrange()` ignores it silently. renaming (or attempt to do so) should error in all cases for `arrange()`. \r\n\r\nHowever, it behaves exactly the same as `distinct()`. (so it is consistent in that sense, but ignores )\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# arrange() is same as distinct() but silently ignores renaming...\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = .data$vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# this rightfully errors!\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `arrange()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `..1 = pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nMaybe a soft-deprecation warning would be desirable for attempting to rename in arrange()\r\nSomething like names ignored, use unnamed, or remove name, or create this variable with mutate() to keep it.\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\n#  A beginner may think that this will create the variable as nothing is stopping them.\r\ny <- mtcars |> arrange(x = vs, y = desc(disp))\r\n\r\n## later tries to access the variable and gets a warning or even worse. This confusing data frame.\r\n\r\ny |> mutate(z = y **2) # gets very bad output!\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n# Suggestions for signaling that `arrange()` ignores renaming.\r\n\r\n1. (preferred) soft-deprecation warning\r\n \r\nsomething like: named input is ignored in arrange(). Please omit them.\r\nin all_of(named_external_selection)  the adjustment required would just be all_of(unname(named_external_selection))\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nx |> arrange(new_var = var)\r\n# now\r\nx |> arrange(var)\r\n```\r\n\r\nif you want to create a new variable or rename, use `rename()` or `mutate()`, as arrange silently ignores names provided.\r\n\r\n\r\n## using the case of tidyselect deprecation of external selection as an example\r\n\r\nit seems pretty similar as the deprecation of `select(.data$vs)` in favour of `select(\"vs\")` + requiring any_of() all_of(). it ended up just increasing\r\ngeneral consitency of code base, and improve clarity.\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# Before when you read this in someone else's code (i.e. with no context)\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(vs)\r\n# you had no idea if the data had a `vs` column, or `vs` was an external vector\r\n# the alternative made everything much clearer.\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(all_of(vs))\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nMy proposed change would force users to remove this potentially misleading code\r\n have the benefit that no one would question if the resulting data frame has a `x` column or not.\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6980 would be addressed automatically as part of this idea. i.e no longer allowing named selection would act a bit like a `check_dots_used()` condition\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# this code is clearer about what it does (and gives the same result as above)\r\n# proposed\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(vs)\r\n```\r\n\r\n2. Breaking change (respect renaming in arrange() i.e. arrange() == mutate() + arrange()), Downsides probably outweigh benefits here at this point..\r\n\r\n\r\nQuoting the 1.1 release notes:\r\n> across(), c_across(), if_any(), and if_all() now require the .cols and .fns arguments. In general, we now recommend that you use pick() instead of an empty across() call or across() with no .fns (e.g. across(c(x, y)). (#6523).\r\n\r\n> Relying on the previous default of .fns = NULL is not yet formally soft-deprecated, because there was no good alternative until now, but it is discouraged and will be soft-deprecated in the next minor release.\r\n\r\nI think that allowing renaming in `pick()` would allow you to soft-deprecate `.fns = NULL` of across and warn on `distinct()` + `across()`.\r\n\r\nEdit: pick() should also allow renaming in` group_by()`",

#>     "body": "This is kind of a weird niche problem. The mutate function is interacting strangely with the ggeffects package when using bind_rows to bind multiple ggeffects objects together then using mutate() to add a column (for both functions ggeffect and ggemmeans). It drops rows for seemingly no reason. There is an easy work around, which is simply to wrap bind_rows in data.frame(), but I figured I'd alert devs to the bug. Anyway, here's a reprex using mtcars.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nrequire(dplyr)\r\nrequire(ggeffects)\r\ndata(mtcars)\r\n# create simple linear models\r\nmodel.fourcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==4,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.sixcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==6,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.eightcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==8,], disp ~ hp)\r\n# doesn't work- drops rows beyond row 7\r\ntest.df <- bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  .id = \"group\") %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n# shows the complete data frame\r\ntest2.df <- data.frame(bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              .id = \"group\")) %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nHere's sessionInfo\r\n\r\n> R version 4.3.2 (2023-10-31 #>     "body": "Currently dplyr warns users who accidentally use `=` instead of `==`. \nHowever, this does not occur if a logical is passed as the named variable.\n\n## Demonstration\n\n\n\n\n\n``` r\nlibrary(dplyr)\n\nmtcars$big_cyl <- mtcars$cyl > 4\n# Mistaking = for == silently fails, returning the whole dataset\nfilter(mtcars, big_cyl = TRUE) |>\n  nrow()\n#> [1] 32\n```\nCorrectly using `==` for comparison\n```r\n# Correctly using ==.\nfilter(mtcars, big_cyl == TRUE) |>\n  nrow()\n#> [1] 21\n```\n\nI think while doing `x == TRUE` is bad practice, this is bound to trip up some users and an error should be thrown.\n\n## Additional context\n\nExample of the error working correctly:\n``` r\n# version 1.1.4\ndplyr::filter(mtcars, cyl = \"4\")\n#> Error in `dplyr::filter()`:\n#> ! We detected a named input.\n#> ℹ This usually means that you've used `=` instead of `==`.\n#> ℹ Did you mean `cyl == \"4\"`?\n```\n\nInterestingly if the TRUE is in a vector the error *is* thrown.\n\n``` r\ndplyr::filter(mtcars, big_cyl = c(TRUE))\n#> Error in `dplyr::filter()`:\n#> ! #>     "body": "I mistakenly used `by`  inside `mutate` instead of `.by`. But no error or warning were raised. I only found this due to a coincidence when I happen to have two pieces of code (one using `by`, the other using `.by`) producing different results.\r\n\r\nI understand that when `by=` is used inside `mutate`, `dplyr` would think I am creating a new column called `by` with values the same as the group variable. There is nothing with the logic.  I just thought an warning or something should be raised because it's such an easy mistake to make. \r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nBelow I include a quick example\r\n\r\n```r\r\nd1 = tibble(x=c(1:6), y=c(rep(1,3), rep(2,3)))\r\n\r\nd1 |> mutate(lag_x = lag(x), by=y)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 6 × 4\r\n#       x     y lag_x    by\r\n# 1     1     1    NA     1\r\n# 2     2     1     1     1\r\n# 3     3     1     2     1\r\n# 4     4     2     3     2\r\n# 5     5     2     4     2\r\n# 6     6     2     5     2\r\n\r\n\r\nd1 |> mutate(lag_x = lag(x), .by=y)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 6 × 3\r\n#       x     y lag_x\r\n# 1     1     1    NA\r\n# 2     2     1     1\r\n# 3     3     1     2\r\n# 4     4     2    NA\r\n# 5     5     2     4\r\n# 6     6     2     5\r\n```\r\n",

This seems to only be an issue if the input to `case_when` is length 1 - it errors otherwise.\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n x <- 5\r\n\r\n# silently returns the wrong thing\r\ndplyr::case_when(\r\n    x == 5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    x > 10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = \"other\"\r\n)\r\n#> character(0)\r\n\r\n# errors\r\ndplyr::case_match(\r\n    x,\r\n    5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = \"other\"\r\n)\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::case_match()`:\r\n#> ! `..2 (right)` must have size 1, not size 0.\r\n\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.1.4'\r\n\r\ny <- 5:7\r\n\r\n# errors out as expected\r\ndplyr::case_when(\r\n    y == 5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    y > 10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = \"other\"\r\n)\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::case_when()`:\r\n#> ! Can't recycle `..1 (left)` (size 3) to match `..2 (right)` (size 0).\r\n\r\n# errors\r\ndplyr::case_match(\r\n    y,\r\n    5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = \"other\"\r\n)\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::case_match()`:\r\n#> ! `..2 (right)` must have size 3, not size 0.\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-09-05 with [reprex v2.1.1](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>\r\n",

This is what the [`{dplyover}`](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover) package allows with its [`across2()` and `across2x()` functions](https://timteafan.github.io/dplyover/reference/across2.html):\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# remotes::install_github(\"TimTeaFan/dplyover\")\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(dplyover)\r\n\r\niris %>% \r\n  group_by(Species) %>%\r\n  summarise(across2x(starts_with(\"Sepal\"), starts_with(\"Petal\"), cor))\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 5\r\n#>   Species   Sepal.Length_Petal.L…¹ Sepal.Length_Petal.W…² Sepal.Width_Petal.Le…³\r\n#>   <fct>                      <dbl>                  <dbl>                  <dbl>\r\n#> 1 setosa                     0.267                  0.278                  0.178\r\n#> 2 versicol…                  0.754                  0.546                  0.561\r\n#> 3 virginica                  0.864                  0.281                  0.401\r\n#> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​Sepal.Length_Petal.Length, ²​Sepal.Length_Petal.Width,\r\n#> #   ³​Sepal.Width_Petal.Length\r\n#> # ℹ 1 more variable: Sepal.Width_Petal.Width <dbl>\r\n\r\ncor(iris[1:50,]$Sepal.Length, iris[1:50,]$Petal.Length)\r\n#> [1] 0.2671758\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-07-17 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n\r\nThe creation of the `{dplyover}` began with this [issue](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4834), which –at that time– recommended putting these features in an adjacent package. \r\n\r\n`{dplyover}` has really saved me and my colleagues a huge amount of time. However, it is not on CRAN, some bugs [[1](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/21), [2](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/23)] have been found, enhancement in the `{dplyr}` package are [not currently supported](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/1), and the last commit is 3 years old.\r\n\r\nDo you think these really useful functions could be included in the `{dplyr}` package? #>     "body": "## Problem\r\n\r\nThanks @AMDraghici for your suggestions!\r\n\r\nFor example, in `bind_rows`, if the first input is a `data.table`, the output table can have corrupt indexing due to how the underlying `dplyr_reconstruct` function deals with the attributes of the two inputs\r\n\r\n## Reprex\r\n\r\nThe example below shows that the index attribute can be incorrect for the output. \r\n\r\n```r\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(5, 2:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"c\") # Create a data.table\r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil. This is necessary for the subset error below to happen in data.table. But it is not necessary to re-produce the corrupted index. \r\n> a[cola == 4] # Give data.table a secondary index (\"cola\" column) by auto-indexing\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$index # The secondary index is set correctly\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, colb = 2, colc=3, cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::bind_rows(list(a,b))\r\n> \r\n> combined # combined is a data.table, with 5 rows\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     5 0.5535855 0.6024416      c\r\n2:     2 0.3407051 0.9291365      c\r\n3:     3 0.5007208 0.6823528      c\r\n4:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n5:    -1 2.0000000 3.0000000      d\r\n> \r\n> attributes(combined)$index # Wrong! length of secondary index is only 4\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 4 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold # Wrong! The last row of combined should be returned\r\n> combined\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola       colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>      <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     1 0.83105427 0.4214379      c\r\n2:     2 0.05702599 0.1354883      c\r\n3:     3 0.63866251 0.1644736      c\r\n4:     4 0.21441544 0.2198251      c\r\n5:    -1 2.00000000 3.0000000      d\r\n```\r\n## Cause\r\n\r\nIn the `bind_rows` function, `dplyr_reconstruct` is used to set attributes for the output dataframe. \r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/R/bind-rows.R#L79\r\n\r\n```r\r\nout <- dplyr_reconstruct(out, first)\r\n```\r\nLooking at the `dplyr_reconstruct` function, it is essentially giving all attributes other than `names` and `row.names` in `template_` to `data`.\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/src/reconstruct.cpp#L36 \r\n\r\nIn the case above, all attributes of `first` (which has four rows), including index are given to `out`, which has five rows. This causes the problem. \r\n\r\n## Impact\r\n\r\nBecause the `data.table` produced by `bind_rows` has corrupted secondary index, the filter functionality of `data.table` is skipping some rows when filtering by the index column. \r\nAlso, I found that this problem is not limited to `bind_rows`. Other `dplyr` functions that calls `dplyr_reconstruct` can result in data.tables with corrupted secondary index. For example, the `full_join` function can also produce unexpected results due to corrupted secondary index.  \r\n\r\n```\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(1:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil\r\n> a[cola == 3]\r\n       cola         colb         colc      cold\r\n   <int>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     3 0.9968646 0.8137836      d\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, cole = \"e\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::full_join(a, b, by = \"cola\")\r\n> \r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 5 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold,cole\r\n```",

#>     "body": "See https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7044\r\n\r\nIn particular, note that `arrange(df, x)` will sort `x` using the C locale if it is a character vector. But `arrange(df, -desc(x))` (i.e. invert the `desc()` call, giving you the original order in theory) will sort `x` using the user's locale.\r\n\r\nNormally a call like `desc(x)` is recognized and we don't even actually call `desc()` under the hood, we translate it to a `\"desc\"` value for the `directions` argument of `vec_order_radix()`, but in this case the `-` interferes and we actually evaluate the call.\r\n\r\nThat ends up calling `desc()` which does `-xtfrm(x)`, and `xtfrm()` ends up using `base::order(x)`, utilizing the user's locale.\r\n\r\nI don't think we should remove usage of `xtfrm()` in `desc()`, since that is a generic that people have probably written S3 methods for, but maybe we can have special behavior for unclassed character vectors where it utilized `vec_rank()` instead (which uses the C locale)? It would not be a perfect fix, but it may be good enough.",

#>     "body": "Should we guarantee that the functions used in a rowwise `mutate()` or `summarize()` or `reframe()` always see length-one input? This is currently the case for everything but empty input, which creates a corner case to be worked around in user code. The example below shows `mutate()`, but the behavior is very similar for `summarize()` and `reframe()`\r\n\r\n``` r\r\noptions(conflicts.policy = list(warn = FALSE))\r\n\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1L) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1:3) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> [1] 2\r\n#> [1] 3\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n#> 2     2          2\r\n#> 3     3          3\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\n# Should this print `NA_integer_` ?\r\ntibble(a = integer()) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> integer(0)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#> # ℹ 2 variables: a <int>, print(a) <int>\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-06-12 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>",

#>     "body": "Hi @hadley and @DavisVaughan,\r\n\r\nThis merge request aims to align the mutate functionality with that of transmute. Presently, the documentation states that the equivalent of transmute is mutate(.keep=\"none\"). However, it's important to note that this function retains the column order, unlike transmute.\r\n\r\nAfter reviewing the bug reported here: https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6861, I concur that there should be a fifth variant of keep, named \"transmute.\"\r\n\r\nThis proposal should also be implemented in the following tidyverse libraries:\r\n- [ ] [dtplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dtplyr)  \r\n- [ ] [dbplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr):  https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr/pull/1508\r\n\r\nAnd in the following third party libraries:\r\n- [ ] [duckplyr](https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr): https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr/pull/176\r\n- [ ] [arrow](https://github.com/apache/arrow/r)\r\n- [ ] [tidypolars](https://github.com/etiennebacher/tidypolars)\r\n\r\nThis change opens the possibility of un-superseded transmute. For example, you could implement that when a user calls transmute, it internally executes mutate(.keep=\"transmute\"). This would greatly benefit veteran users who have extensively used transmute in their projects. Additionally, it improves code readability, as a simple transmute call is clearer than mutate(.keep=\"transmute\").\r\n\r\nBelow I leave an example comparing transmute with mutate(.keep = \"transmute\")\r\n\r\n```\r\nexample <- tibble(\r\n  group = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\"),\r\n  old = c(1, 2, 3, 4)\r\n)\r\n\r\n# transmute --------------------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% transmute(\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") --------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% mutate(\r\n  .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + transmute ---------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  transmute(\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") ---------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\", by = ...) ----------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>%  \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    .by = \"group\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n  )\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nRegards,\r\n\r\n",

#>     "body": "This would be useful in packages to avoid cran warnings as `pick()` is the new preferred way.\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\noptions(lifecycle_verbosity = \"error\")\r\nmtcars <- utils::head(mtcars, n = 6)\r\n# distinct -----------\r\n# renaming generally makes a lot of sense, as distinct is like `transmute(...)` + `distinct()`\r\n# consider this in EDA\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = vs)\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\n# as it is equivalent to: (to avoid cran warnings)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = .data$vs)\r\n# Before dplyr 1.1, `across()` was recommended, which works, but .fns = NULL is soft-deprecated.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# The alternative when you may not know variable names in a package\r\n# with `pick()` should therefore work too, but errors.\r\n# I think it should work\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `distinct()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n# Similarly:\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n\r\n# I would expect distinct() and transmute()  + distinct() to be same as above (and it is!) ---\r\n# transmute() is still very useful as it is mutate + select in a single call)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = .data$vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n# I think this should be allowed.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#> Error in `transmute()`:\r\n#> ℹ In argument: `pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nNow comes `arrange()`...\r\n\r\n## arrange() \r\n\r\nWhile I believe `distinct()` should accept renaming under any circonstances, I believe that accepting renaming in `arrange()` is inconsistent, as `arrange()` ignores it silently. renaming (or attempt to do so) should error in all cases for `arrange()`. \r\n\r\nHowever, it behaves exactly the same as `distinct()`. (so it is consistent in that sense, but ignores )\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# arrange() is same as distinct() but silently ignores renaming...\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = .data$vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# this rightfully errors!\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `arrange()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `..1 = pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nMaybe a soft-deprecation warning would be desirable for attempting to rename in arrange()\r\nSomething like names ignored, use unnamed, or remove name, or create this variable with mutate() to keep it.\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\n#  A beginner may think that this will create the variable as nothing is stopping them.\r\ny <- mtcars |> arrange(x = vs, y = desc(disp))\r\n\r\n## later tries to access the variable and gets a warning or even worse. This confusing data frame.\r\n\r\ny |> mutate(z = y **2) # gets very bad output!\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n# Suggestions for signaling that `arrange()` ignores renaming.\r\n\r\n1. (preferred) soft-deprecation warning\r\n \r\nsomething like: named input is ignored in arrange(). Please omit them.\r\nin all_of(named_external_selection)  the adjustment required would just be all_of(unname(named_external_selection))\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nx |> arrange(new_var = var)\r\n# now\r\nx |> arrange(var)\r\n```\r\n\r\nif you want to create a new variable or rename, use `rename()` or `mutate()`, as arrange silently ignores names provided.\r\n\r\n\r\n## using the case of tidyselect deprecation of external selection as an example\r\n\r\nit seems pretty similar as the deprecation of `select(.data$vs)` in favour of `select(\"vs\")` + requiring any_of() all_of(). it ended up just increasing\r\ngeneral consitency of code base, and improve clarity.\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# Before when you read this in someone else's code (i.e. with no context)\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(vs)\r\n# you had no idea if the data had a `vs` column, or `vs` was an external vector\r\n# the alternative made everything much clearer.\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(all_of(vs))\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nMy proposed change would force users to remove this potentially misleading code\r\n have the benefit that no one would question if the resulting data frame has a `x` column or not.\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6980 would be addressed automatically as part of this idea. i.e no longer allowing named selection would act a bit like a `check_dots_used()` condition\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# this code is clearer about what it does (and gives the same result as above)\r\n# proposed\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(vs)\r\n```\r\n\r\n2. Breaking change (respect renaming in arrange() i.e. arrange() == mutate() + arrange()), Downsides probably outweigh benefits here at this point..\r\n\r\n\r\nQuoting the 1.1 release notes:\r\n> across(), c_across(), if_any(), and if_all() now require the .cols and .fns arguments. In general, we now recommend that you use pick() instead of an empty across() call or across() with no .fns (e.g. across(c(x, y)). (#6523).\r\n\r\n> Relying on the previous default of .fns = NULL is not yet formally soft-deprecated, because there was no good alternative until now, but it is discouraged and will be soft-deprecated in the next minor release.\r\n\r\nI think that allowing renaming in `pick()` would allow you to soft-deprecate `.fns = NULL` of across and warn on `distinct()` + `across()`.\r\n\r\nEdit: pick() should also allow renaming in` group_by()`",

#>     "body": "This is kind of a weird niche problem. The mutate function is interacting strangely with the ggeffects package when using bind_rows to bind multiple ggeffects objects together then using mutate() to add a column (for both functions ggeffect and ggemmeans). It drops rows for seemingly no reason. There is an easy work around, which is simply to wrap bind_rows in data.frame(), but I figured I'd alert devs to the bug. Anyway, here's a reprex using mtcars.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nrequire(dplyr)\r\nrequire(ggeffects)\r\ndata(mtcars)\r\n# create simple linear models\r\nmodel.fourcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==4,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.sixcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==6,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.eightcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==8,], disp ~ hp)\r\n# doesn't work- drops rows beyond row 7\r\ntest.df <- bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  .id = \"group\") %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n# shows the complete data frame\r\ntest2.df <- data.frame(bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              .id = \"group\")) %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nHere's sessionInfo\r\n\r\n> R version 4.3.2 (2023-10-31 ## Use I() to force body part to be sent as an array, even if length 1
## This works whether assignees has length 1 or > 1
assignees <- "gh_user"
assignees <- c("gh_user1", "gh_user2")
gh("PATCH /repos/OWNER/REPO/issues/1", assignees = I(assignees))
}
if (FALSE) {
## There are two ways to send JSON data. One is that you supply one or
## more objects that will be converted to JSON automatically via
## jsonlite::toJSON(). In this case sometimes you need to use
## jsonlite::unbox() because fromJSON() creates lists from scalar vectors
## by default. The Content-Type header is automatically added in this
## case. For example this request turns on GitHub Pages, using this
## API: https://docs.github.com/v3/repos/pages/#enable-a-pages-site

gh::gh(
  "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",
  owner = "r-lib",
  repo = "gh",
  source = list(
    branch = jsonlite::unbox("gh-pages"),
    path = jsonlite::unbox("/")
  ),
  .send_headers = c(Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json")
)

## The second way is to handle the JSON encoding manually, and supply it
## as a raw vector in an unnamed argument, and also a Content-Type header:

body <- '{ "source": { "branch": "gh-pages", "path": "/" } }'
gh::gh(
  "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",
  owner = "r-lib",
  repo = "gh",
  charToRaw(body),
  .send_headers = c(
    Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json",
    "Content-Type" = "application/json"
  )
)
}
if (FALSE) {

            )
